text: what relationship has the Platform Name and Version to the fabric release level?
<@U0KPFAZNF>: ^^
i see them as independent, or at least that was the intent
like java 1.8
supposed to imply a specific ABI that the chaincode could rely upon
hmmm
right now, its not strictly controlled, but eventually I see that as perhaps locking things down like the shim API
maybe golang 1.6, etc
right now, “the platform” ends up being whatever stuff the VP that builds it happens to have
would make sense if we versioned the shim api
but that needs to change eventually
yes, i think so
I think it really should be independent of the fabric release
yes, i was envisioning that “platform/ver” might correlate 1:1 with a docker image
that has the shim, golang, etc, baked in
so each shim independent? I guess that’s right
(or whatever is appropriate, obviously a java platform would have different things in it
we should have a discussion about our project organization
one repo was a good idea but has lost some of its luster
yeah, my gut feeling is we should let the protobuf schema be the compatibility mechanism
version the shim API, let clients code to a specific version of it, etc
despite my loathing of submodules, we probably need to go there
oh god no, please
heh
lol
i used them on a major project here, it was a nightmare
I know
I suppose we could go with normal dependencies
if you were a git ninja and knew all the details of the project, it was fine
yeah
anyone new coming in would make a complete mess of their checkout, though
separate repos, publish a release in whatever appropriate form and handle the interdependencies as dependencies?
yeah, something like that
i think strictly speaking, the shim doesnt need to be in a sep repo, but that might be a good idea in general
well, yes, but it would make it clearer that there were no unexpected dependencies
from a versioning perspective, it doesnt matter too much, but we are seeing weirdness with GOPATH/vendoring simply because of the topology choice
right, i agree
just logically makes things cleaner
I don’t think that vendoring just the <http://github.com/hypereldger/fabric/core/chaincode/shim|github.com/hypereldger/fabric/core/chaincode/shim> works
hyperledger/fabric-shim, has different langs in there etc
at least I had some issues with it a while back
yeah, it doesnt…it gets messed up because of the vendoring up higher in the tree
right
so for that reason alone...
which if it were separate would make cleaner
the other reason is it might be goofy to have, say, java and nodejs shims along side the current one in the current topology
might be cleaner to have hyperledger/fabric-shim.git/[golang, java, nodejs] etc
or maybe they each get their own?
hyperledger/fabric-shim-golang, etc
that way each shim team can manage their own releases a little cleaner, etc
well, the dependency management are all different
yes
right, thats what i meant really
releases+dep management
eg node npm, java maven, go etc
right
i like the hyperledger/fabric-shim-[golang|java|nodejs].git proposal
yes
now, where do we keep the protobuf?
wouldn’t it be nice if all the APIs were abstracted out entirely in the protobuf specification interactions … so we can make that the main thing all the above
-[core]?
I think you read my mind <@U0KM61BCP> ?
:slightly_smiling_face:
<@U0ULK2JPP>: agree, that should be the contract
im torn on the .proto topic
on one hand, I loath duplication
hmmm
on the other hand, each project having its own sense of the current contract is exactly what happens in reality
(on the wire, i mean)
right. I think its worth preventing right at get-go
One way to concretize that is by “pointing” to the common proto (which I think is what <@U0KM61BCP> suggests ?)
submodule (ducks)
whats been working reasonably well from me lately is that ill keep the .protos in one place, but I keep the intermediates checked into the project
(such as the .pb.go)
yea
hmmm
that way, the definition is in one place, but the ABI is stable for a project until someone takes explicit action to update them
how do we manage the affinity?
no way to prevent that kind of “generation” for cross-language
I should have said for “multiple” languges … the files would have to be generated for each
<@U0KM61BCP>: what do you mean by affinity?
well, if I understood you correctly, you were suggesting maintain the .proto centrally and generate the lang specific .pb.go/java eyc
etc
and then you check those into the lang specific repo?
I guess if the commit message were crystal clear...
would want to track which commit the .pb.* was built from

right, so you could have the protos remain in fabric.git, and something like a “make protos” directive in your subordinate project that will take some reference to the proto you want and generate intermediate artifacts that get checked in to the subordinate project
oh i see what you are getting at
hmm, i guess I havent run into the situation where that matters per se
but I see your point
for debugging when there’s a mismatch
yeah…i mean, if no one breaks the rules, it “shouldnt matter”, but I do see your concern
if for anything, sanity
y
so when we generate for one language, we generate all ?
would that take care of the problem ?
i dont think so
ok
because the different projects might update at different times
right
each update potentially requires a code update to go with it
could we use a make rule that d/l’s the build artefact?
one thing that could be done is something like “make protos” copies the proto to the subordinate project with a “DO NOT EDIT, see <http://blah>” at the top or something
so its known that this is not the authoritative source
another idea, we could compute a hash/reference to the one we built from and include that in metadata
or another idea, just stop worrying about the dup and let projects copy the .proto into their project that they want to support
heh
curl -XGET <https://raw.githubusercontent.com/hyperledger/fabric/master/core/chaincode/shim/proto.pb.go> etc
(ive done that too)
well, to be clear, i wouldnt recommend we pull intermediates
just .protos at the most
yes, that could work
but would need to be tied to a release
hmmm
not necessarily
only the user knows what version of the contract they want, really, but generally most updates are going to be “latest"
well, let’s say I want to fix a defect in a previous release
ah, yes, i see where you are going
I don’t want the current master .proto
right
I think those giturls can have tags, etc in them
but maybe we are overcomplicating things
maybe the best thing is just let the projects have whatever .proto they want
thats their ABI contract, some may stay on an old one forever, some may track latest religiously, and if someone wants to do something weird and edit locally, thats their business
but a disciplined project would track the contract they want to support in a timeline that makes sense to their project
by ^^^ i just mean, maybe the “central place” is too complicated
maybe just let the apps maintain the .proto/intermediates how they want
then, if foo/branchA needs fabric/branchY .proto update, a human just grabs what they need
is that punting?
<@U0ULK2JPP>: when you get a chance: <https://github.com/hyperledger/fabric-chaintool/pull/18>

attachments.title: v1.0 release and v1.1-SNAPSHOT prep by ghaskins · Pull Request #18 · hyperledger/fabric-chaintool · GitHub
attachments.text: This PR creates a v1.0 release and adjusts master to continue on with v1.1-SNAPSHOT. After merge, I will create a tag/release on the 3fb6ded commit
attachments.fallback: GitHub: v1.0 release and v1.1-SNAPSHOT prep by ghaskins · Pull Request #18 · hyperledger/fabric-chaintool

text: do you think 1.0 is appropriate given the conservatism expressed by the TSC members?
for chaintool?
y
it doesnt strike me as particularly controversial, but if you think otherwise i am open to that
i was just thinking “its stable, it does pretty much what I set out to do, blah blah"
so it made sense to me
but if that implies something that might be frowned upon by others, I am not married to it
I am not saying it isn't
i could tag it v0.8, which is what it would have been otherwise
(a new release is def in order, the actual tag doesnt matter much
that would likely be better received
ok, i can do that
we’re going to be using <http://semver.org|semver.org>
(previous release was v0.7
yeah, and if you want to tag a release candidate you could append -rc1 etc
or maybe v0.7.1, id have to look
yeah, though personally i think the project is too small to go through a -rc formality
but again, i am open if that is the process we want
going from 0.7 to 1.0 means not backwards compatible
oh i see where you are going
although there is some flexibility for the initial releases
thats not the case, but I see what you mean
yeah, generally I do my releases where v0.x = all bets are off
actually, thats not true
what I do is I treat v0.x.y where x is the compatible and y is the point release
until it hits 1.0
I use v0.x.y to just mean “its not fully baked project yet"
but, related to your point: do you think releases need to be done more formally?
i was not really thinking about that, thus the simple PR
ill retract the PR and resubmit as v0.8, unless you think that also needs to go through some other process
<@U0KM61BCP>: I actually wasn’t on the TSC call yesterday (and I also missed a few in the last few weeks due to vacation)
no worries
was there something discussed particularly about chaintool/conservatism that i missed?]
no
or was this about general conservatism with releases, etc
we have been discussing exit criteria from Incubation which set off discussion of release taxonomy and maturity assessment
ah, ok, i did hear part of that conversation last week, i think
so generally, we will want to have clear and unambiguous release taxonomy and set expectations accordingly
so, reading between the lines, i am guessing you are equating “1.0” with “exit incubation"
right, got it
this makes sense
def didnt mean to imply anything along those lines
well, incubation is about the project TEAM’s maturity, not the code necessarily
(still adapting to “my pet project” to “accepted upstream” ;)
chaintool is pretty mature
but when we get to naming something 1.0, the expectation will be that will be suitable for production deployments, I think
tbh, i didnt really think much about the version number, just knew I wanted a new release so I can update fabric to use it
eg our first production release
yeah, this makes sense
kind of like what Docker did
right
v0.8 or whatever is fine, or even v0.7.1
yep
(i already have v0.7 out there)
if it is just tweaks and fixes 0.7.1 is fine
ive tended to bump v0.x def for abi compat, but even for feature additions
also too you could do 0.8.0 if you wanted to make a statement
I’ve added a few new features since v0.7, thus the bump
but its not strictly critical
makes sense
(to delineate, i mean)
ok, sounds good
discuss on ML first, or just a 0.7.1/0.8 PR is fine?
stepping out for a run, bbiab
you should send announce to ml yes
looks like you could use some .gitignore rules for build artefacts
I’ll add if you like
done PR pushed
having some issues building in the vagrant environment
1) JDK not installed - I don’t understand this because we now have the java shim, maybe I need to vagrant destroy and vagrant up to refresh
2) /usr/local/bin is owned by root and not writable
had to sudo make install
you know what would be nice, is if we could have the node client work with context
so that you don’t spend all your time cutting and pasting hashes and fqps
<@U0KM61BCP>: <http://lists.hyperledger.org/pipermail/hyperledger-technical-discuss/2016-July/000346.html>
ill take alook at your PR, seems reasonable
regarding JDK, i thought we installed that but maybe it is JRE
me too
I rebuilt vagrant
regarding 2, that should be an easy fix (for vagrant at least)
must have been old
sudo make install
oh, i was thinking we could make /usr/local writable by uid:vagrant
but that works too :wink:
i havent run into either of these because I build on my mac and run it in vagrant via the /local-dev
e.g. I do export PATH=/local-dev/path/to/chaintool/target:$PATH
but that is a reasonable workflow too
oh of course
so we pick up the shim package because fabric is in the $GOPATH?
that’s an unstated dependency for chaintool
might want to make that clear
yes, though it will also just put HEAD from github if you dont happen to have it
pull HEAD, i mean
in theory you can run chaintool on a completely pristine environment and it will use go-get to get anything not found
eventually, we need to have platform/version mean something specific, though
(but we dont have this in normal chaincode dev yet either
so not like chaintool broke this
